docs.lead_paragraph: Children and men of late middle age face a common peril: they share the distinction of having the highest risk of losing part of a finger. For children, a new study in Annals of Emergency Medicine reports, the risk is usually from doors at home or in the car. For men, beware the power tools. The study, prepared by researchers at the National Center for Injury Prevention and Control, was led by Judith M. Conn.
docs.abstract: Judith M Conn of National Center for Injury Prevention and Control leads study that identifies young children and middle age men as most likely to have fingertip or full finger amputations as result of accident; research is published in Annals of Emergency Medicine; children are most often injured by doors and men from power tools; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Children and men of late middle age face a common peril: they share the distinction of having the highest risk of losing part of a finger.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
